Merged pull request "Major TypeScript module refactoring" (#1319) at aspnet/SignalR
Events.RelatedBody:
This is a bit large, but it should be fairly straightforward, there's no functional code change, just some restructuring.

1. Split @aspnet/signalr-client into two packages: @aspnet/signalr (base) and @aspnet/signalr-protocol-msgpack (msgpack extension)
    * Also split tests!
2. Remove MSBuild projects for npm modules. It was a weird hybrid. I might try to reintroduce them if people really want them. The net effect is that you can't use full VS to edit them easily, but VSCode works great.
3. Restructure package.json devDependencies to avoid duplication
4. Remove gulp, just use NPM scripts to automate
5. Build four outputs for each package:
    * [ECMAScript Module](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/import) using ES2016 in `dist/esm` (future-proofing "best practice" used by many packages)
    * [CommonJS Module](http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Modules/1.1.1) using ES5 in `dist/cjs` (for NodeJS)
    * [UMD Module](https://github.com/umdjs/umd) using ES5 in `dist/browser` (for Browser), including minified version (using uglify-js)
    * TypeScript Definitions
6. Use [Rollup](https://rollupjs.org/) to produce the UMD module, it's like browserify but with tree-shaking to reduce unused polyfill code
7. Only produce the ES5 version for the browser. Most people seem to want to use that, the ES2016 version was extraneous. If you're targetting only ES2016 browsers, use the `dist/esm` files natively or with something like webpack/rollup. We can always revisit this.
8. Integrate new NPM packages into the build.
9. Convert the functional tests to use TypeScript (it was a pain that they were the only things that didn't use that ;))

~~TODO:~~ Done!
* [x] Clean up git ignores and reverify samples (some of the code the FunctionalTests use is still in there, will fix shortly)
* [x] Finish reintegrating npm packaging with the build
* [x] Verify functional tests on IE (the least-compatible browser ;))
* [x] Review need for `msgpackshim` func.

```
Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.Compilation.CompilationFailedException: One or more compilation failures occurred:
(0,0): Error RZ3900: Could not find an 'Invoke' or 'InvokeAsync' method for the view component 'TestViewComponent'

   w Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.Internal.RazorViewCompiler.CreateCacheEntry(String normalizedPath)

   w System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   w System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   w Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.Internal.DefaultRazorPageFactoryProvider.CreateFactory(String relativePath)
   w Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Razor.RazorViewEngine.CreateCacheResult(HashSet`1 expirationTokens, String relativePath, Boolean isMainPage)

        public override Task<IViewComponentResult> InvokeAsync(int someId)

`public abstract class MyViewComponent<X, Y>` with method:

I've found error message `Could not find an '{0}' or '{1}' method for the view component '{2}'.` in mvc source code and tried launching `DefaultViewComponentDescriptorProvider.FindMethod` on my TestViewComponent class, and it was discovered correctly (without exception).

I am unable to create repo reproducing this. If I just create Aspnet2.0 application it works, If I try to extract controllers and viewComponents to separate assembly I am getting UnresolvedReferences to everything.

I have ClassLibrary with Startup, my Controllers and ViewComponents, Mvc references, etc. Then I have WebApplication just with Program.cs pointing to dll and views. Running on full framework .net 4.6.1 on windows.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Kestrel Freezes" (#2262) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody:
Kestrel based websocket app becomes unresponsive at random intervals in production.  Reproduction is difficult, and relies upon running with load and monitoring for unresponsiveness.  Once unresponsive the only remedy is to stop the process gracefully and restart.

Environment: AWS, Ubuntu 16.04, Kestrel 2.0.0, AspNetCore 2.0.0

LLDB shows two threads with `System.ObjectDisposedException` exceptions, both with the following call-stack:
```

00007FDC4EFFC4E0 00007fdf29543360 [HelperMethodFrame: 00007fdc4effc4e0] 
00007FDC4EFFC600 00007FDEB0424623 Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.Http.FrameResponseStream.ValidateState(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
00007FDC4EFFC630 00007FDEB042444F Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.Http.FrameResponseStream.WriteAsync(Byte[], Int32, Int32, System.Threading.CancellationToken)

00007FDC4EFFC750 00007FDEB06DC20A System.Net.WebSockets.ManagedWebSocket.SendKeepAliveFrameAsync()
00007FDC4EFFC790 00007FDEB06DE2B9 System.Net.WebSockets.ManagedWebSocket+<>c.<.ctor>b__38_1(System.Object)
00007FDC4EFFC7A0 00007FDEAE701011 System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(System.Threading.ExecutionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback, System.Object)

I've tried to use "dotnet build -r win7-x86" and it would create the right folder "bin\Debug\net46\win7-x86" and then I can run the ".exe" file.

Still cannot test the application in x86 mode.

Then I've uninstalled Microsoft .NET Code 1.0.0 RC2 - SDK Preview 1 (x64) which was installed via "VS 2015 Tooling Preview" and installed the "x86" one, and everything seems to be working.

I think it is not right. I should be have the option to install x64 and x86 and then via that buildOption I should be able to tell dotnet how to compile. Just like MSBuild and ASP.Net projects where I set the build options from Project Properties.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Question: Typescript with ASP.NET Core RC2" (#557) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody:
Is it possible to compile Typescript code directly in Visual Studio 2015 using the ASP.NET Core RC2 project templates?  This used to work in RC1, but since updating to RC2 I can't get Typescript and ASP.NET Core working together simultaneously.  If I create a .NET Core project (e.g., **ASP.NET Core Web Application (.NET Core)** template), then I don't see "Typescript Build" properties page in Project Properties (the only property pages available are Application, Build, Debug).  I can create a Typescript project (e.g., **HTML Application with Typescript** template, which uses the csproj format), and Typescript works as expected, but of course I can't use .NET Core in that project.

I have confirmed that my .xproj file does include a reference to Microsoft.DotNet.Web.targets, which I understand is supposed to bring in Typescript support:

```
<Import Project="$(VSToolsPath)\DotNet.Web\Microsoft.DotNet.Web.targets"
        Condition="'$(VSToolsPath)' != ''" />
```

Is the built-in Typescript compilation no longer supported with RC2, or am I missing something somewhere?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove project file elements added for WebApiCompatShim in 2.0" (#286) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.WebApiCompatShim package now depends on the latest (5.2.4-preview1) Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.Client package. That dependency includes a new .NET Standard 2.0 assembly. This assembly supports all platforms the Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.WebApiCompatShim package supports and includes the full Web API Client feature set.

When upgrading projects using the Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.WebApiCompatShim package to our nightly builds or the forthcoming 2.1.0-preview1 release, we recommend removing the following elements from the project file. (Of course, some projects may need the elements for other reasons.)
``` xml
<PackageTargetFallback>$(PackageTargetFallback);portable-net451+win8</PackageTargetFallback>
<DisableImplicitAssetTargetFallback>true</DisableImplicitAssetTargetFallback>
```

FYI the `<PackageTargetFallback>` element caused the application to build and run against the Portable Class Library (PCL) assembly from the Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.Client package.

For discussion of this change, see aspnet/Mvc#7229.

Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE-2018-0785 - ASP.NET Core Templates enable Cross Site Request Forgery" (#284) at aspnet/Announcements
Opened issue "Using the "Home" repo for issue management of other repos" (#283) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi all,

We are experimenting to try and use the [Home repo's issue tracker](https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues) to manage issues for multiple repos. To start with, we have moved the bugs from several other repos to the Home repo, and we will retire the issue trackers of those other repos.

We are doing this to try to improve the experience of logging issues for ASP.NET Core.

* Labels in the form of `repo:RepoName` are used to associate the bug with a product/feature area
* For issue trackers that moved to the Home repo, please log new issues in the Home repo. If a bug is logged in a moved issue tracker, it will be closed.
* Over time, we plan to consolidate more issue trackers into the Home repo

For discussions on this topic, please go to https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2736.

Thanks,
Eilon
